titleStmt.title: A machine=readable version of Gammer Gurton's Needle

publicationStmt.publisher: A ryght pithy, pleasaunt and merie comedie: intytuled Gammer gurtons nedle played on stage, not longe a go in Christes Colledge in Cambridge. Made by Mr. S. Mr. of Art., Imprynted at London : In Fleetestreat beneth the Conduit at the signe of S. Iohn Enangelist [sic] by Thomas Colwell, [1575]

The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Gammer Gurton Diccon Hodge Tib Cock Dame Chat Doctor Rat Master Bailey
Prologue

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.l: As Gamer Gurton, with many a wide stitch
Sat pesing and patching of Hodgher mass breech
By chance or misfortune as she her gear tossed
In Hodge leather breeches her needle she lost,
When Diccon the bedlam had hard by report
That good Gamer Gurton was robbed in this sort,
He quietly persuaded with her in that stound
Dame Chat her dear gossip this needle had found,
Yet knew she no more of this matter (alas)
Than knoweth Tom our clarke what the Priest saith at mass
Here of there ensued so fearful a fray,
Mass Doctor was sent for these gossips to staye,
Because he was Curate, and esteemed full wise
Who found that he sought not, by Diccons device,
When all things were tumbled and clean out of fashion
Whether it were by fortune, or some other constellation
Suddenly the needle Hodge found by the pricking
And drew it out of his buttock where he felt it sticking
Their hearts then at rest with perfect security,
With a pot of good ale they stroke up their plaudity.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Many a mile have I walked, diners and sundry ways
And many a good mass house have I been at in my days
Many a gossips cup in my time have I tasted
And many a brach and spit, have I both turned and basted
Many a piece of bacon have I had out of their balks
In running over the country, with long and were walks,
Yet came my foot never, within those door cheeks,
To seek flesh or fish, Garlic, Onions or Leeks,
That ever I saw a sort, in such a plight
As here within this house appeareth to my sight,
There is howling and scowling, all cast in a dump,
With whewling and pewling, as though they had lost a trump
Sighing and sobbing, they weep and they wail
I marvel in my mind, what the devil they ail
The old Trot sits groaning, with alas and alas,
And Tib wrings her hands, and takes on in worse case
With poor Cocke their boy, they be driven in such fits
I fear me the folks be not well in their wits,
Ask them what they ail, or who brought them in this staye?
They answer not at all, but alack and welaway
When I saw it booted not, out at doors I hied me
And caught a slip of Bacon, when I saw that none spied me,
Which I intend not far hence, unless my purpose fail
Shall serve for a shoeing horn to draw on two pots of ale.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: See so I am arrayed with dabbling in the dirt
She that set me to ditching, I would she had the squirt
Was never poor soul that such a life had?
Gog's bones this filthy glaye has dressed me too bad
Gods soul, see how this stuff tears
I were better to be a Bearward and set to keep Bears
By the Mass here is a gash, a shameful hole in deed
If one stitch tear further, a man may thrust in his head.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: By my fathers soul Hodge, if I should now besworn
I cannot choose but say thy breech is foul be torn,
But the next remedy in such a case and hap
Is to plaunch on a piece, as broad as thy cap.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Gog's soul man, it is not yet two days fully ended
Since my dame Gurton ( I am sure) these breeches amended,
But I am made such a drudge to trudge at every need
I would rend it though it were stitched what sturdy pack thread,

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Hoge, let thy breeches go, and speak and tell me soon
What devil aileth gamer gurton, and Tib her maid to frown,

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Tush man thou art deceived, it is their daily look,
They cour so over the coals, their eyes be bleared with smoke,

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Nay by the mass, I perfectly perceived as I came hither
That either Tib and her dame hath been by the ears together
Or else as great a matter as thou shalt shortly see.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Now I beseech our Lord they never better agree.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: By gog's soul there they sit as still as stones in the street
As though they had been take with fairies or else with some ill sprite

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Gog's heart, I durst have laid my cap to a crown
I would learn of some prancome as soon as ich came to town.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Why Hodge art thou inspired? or didst thou thereof hear ?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Nay, but I saw such a wonder as I saw not this seven year
Tome Tankards Cow (be gog's bones) she set me up her sail
And flinging about his half acre fisking with her tail,
As though there had been in her arse a swarm of Bees,
If I had not cried through whore, she had leapt out of his Lees.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Why Hodg lies the conning in Tom tankards cow's tail?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Well I have hard some say such tokens do not fail,
But canst you not tell in faith Diccon, why she frowns or whereat
Hath no man stolen her Ducks or Hens, or gelded gib her Cat

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: What devil can I tell man, I could not have one word
They gave no more heed to my talk than thou wouldst to a lord

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I cannot still but muse, what marvelous thing it is
I will in and know myself what matters are amiss.

sp.speaker: Diccon.
sp.l: Then farewell hodge a while, since thou dost inward haste,
For I will into the good wife Chats, to feele how the ale doth taste.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I am aghast by the mass, I wot not what to do
I had need bless me well before I go them to
Perchance some felon spirit may haunt our house indeed,
And then I were but at noddy to venture where I have no need

sp.speaker: Tib,
sp.l: I am worse than mad by the mass to be at this staye
I am chid, I am blamed, and beaten all the hours on the day,
Lamed and hunger starved, pricked up all in Jags
Having no patch to hyde my back, save a few rotten rags.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I say Tyb, if thou be Tyb, as I trow sure thou be,
What devil make a do is this, between our dame and thee.

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: Gog's bread Hodg thou had a good turn thou wert not here this while .
It had been better for some of us to have been hence a mile
My Gammer is so out of course, and frantic all at ones
That Cocke our boy, and I poor wench, have felt it on our bones.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: What is the matter, say on Tib whereat she taketh so on.

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: She is undone she sayeth alas, her joy and life is gone
If she hear not of some comfort, she is sayeth but dead
Shall never come within her lips, one inch of meat ne bread.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Byrlady I am not very glad, to see her in this dump
I hold a noble her stole hath fallen, and she hath broke her rump

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: Nay and that were the worst, we would not greatly care
For bursting of her huckle bone, or breaking of her Chair,
But greater, greater, is her grief, as hodge we shall all feele.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Gog's wounds Tyb, my gammer has never lost her Needle?

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: Her Needle.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Her Needle?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Her needle by him that made me, it is true Hodge I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Gog's sacrament, I would she had lost, the heart out of her belly
The Devil or else his dame, they ought her sure a shame
How a murryon came this chance, (say Tib) unto our dame?

sp.speaker: Tyb
sp.l: My gamer sat her down on her pes, and bad me reach thy breeches
And by and by, a vengeance in it or she had take two stitches
To clap a clout upon thine arse, by chance a side she leers
And gyb our cat in the milk pan, she spied over head and ears
Ah whore, out thief, she cried aloud, and swept the breeches down
Up went her staff, and out leapt gyb, at doors into the town
And since that time was never wight, could set their eyes upon it
Gog's malison chaue Cocke and I, bid twenty times light on it.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: And is not then my breeches sewed up, tomorrow that I should wear

sp.speaker: Tyb
sp.l: No in faith hodge thy breeches lie, for all this never the near.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Now a vengeance light on all the sort, that better should have kept it,
The cat, the house, and tib our maid, that better should have swept it
Se where she cometh crawling, come on in twenty devils way
Ye have made a fair days work, have you not? pray you say.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Alas hoge, alas I may well curse and ban
This day that ever I saw it, with gyb and the milk pan
For these and ill luck to gather, as knoweth Cocke my boy
Have stack away my dear needle, and robbed me of my joy
My fair long straight needle that was mine only treasure
The fyrst day of my sorrow is, and last end of my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Might have kept it when ye had it, but fools will be fools still .
Lose that is vast in your hands, ye need not but ye will.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Go hie thee tib, and run thou whore, to the end here of the town
Didst carry out dust in thy lap, seek where thou pourest it down
And as thou sawest me raking, in the ashes where I morned
So see in all the heap of dust, thou leave no straw unturned.

sp.speaker: Tyb
sp.l: That I shall gammer swythe and tight, and soon be here again,

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Tib stoop and look down to the ground to it, and take some pain.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Here is a pretty matter, to see this gear how it goes
By gog's soul I think you would lose your arse, and it were loose
Your needle lost, it is pity you should lack care and endless sorrow
Gog's death how shall my breeches be sewed, shall I go thus tomorrow

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Ah hodg, hodg, if that I could find my needle by the reed
I could sow thy breeches I promise ye with full good double thread
And set a patch on either knee, should last this months twain
Now god and good Saint Sithe I pray, to send it home again.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Whereto served your hands and eyes, but this your needle to keep
What devil had you else to do, ye kept I wot no sheep
I am fain abroad to dig and delve, in water, mire and clay
Sossing and possing in the dirt, still from day to day
A hundred things that be abroad, I am set to see them well
And four of you sit idle at home, and cannot keep a needle.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: My needle alas I lost it hodge, what time I me up hasted
To save the milk set up for the, which gib our cat hath wasted

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: The Devil he burst both gib, and Tib, with all the rest
I am always sure of the worst end, who ever have the best
Where have you been fidging abroad, since you your needle lost

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Within the house, and at the door, sitting by this same post
Where I was looking a long hour, before these folks came here,
But welaway, all was in vain, my needle is never the near.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Set me a candle, let me seek and grope where ever it be
Gog's heart ye be so foolish I think ) you know it not when you it see

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Come hither Cocke, what Cocke I say.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: How Gammer.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Go hie thee soon, and grope behind the old brass pan,
Which thing when thou hast done
There shalt thou find an old shoe, where in if thou look well
Thou shalt find lying an inch of a white tallow candle,
Light it, and bring it tight away.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: That shall be done anon.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Nay tarry hodg till thou hast light, and then we will seek each one.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Come away ye whoreson boy, are ye asleep : ye must have a crier.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: I cannot get the candle light here is almost no fire.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I will hold thee a penny I will make ye come if that I may catch thine ears
Art deaf thou whoreson boy? cocke I say, why canst not hears.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Beat him not Hodge but help the boy and come you two together.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: How now Tyb, quick let us hear, what news thou hast brought hither.

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: I have tossed and tumbled yonder heap over and over again
And winnowed it through my fingers, as me would winnow grain
Not so much as a hens turd but in pieces I tare it
Or what so ever clod or clay I found, I did not spare it
Looking within and eke without, to find your needle (alas)
But all in vain and without help, your needle is where it was.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Alas my needle we shall never meet, adieu, adieu for aye.

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: Not so gammer, we might it find if we knew where it lay.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: Gog's cross Gammer if ye will laugh look in but at the door
And see how Hodg lieth tumbling and tossing amids the flower
Raking there some fire to find among the ashes dead
Where there is not one spark, so big as a pins head,
At last in a dark corner two sparks he thought he sees
Which where indeed naught else but Gyb our cats two eyes
Puff quoth hodg thinking thereby to have fire without doubt
With that Gyb shut her two eyes, and so the fire was out
And by and by them opened, even as they were before,
With that the sparks appeared even as they had done of yore,
And even as hodge blew the fire as he did think
Gyb as she felt the blast straight way began to wink,
Till Hodge fell of swearing, as came best to his turn,
The fire was sure bewitched, and therefore would not burn:
At last Gyb up the stairs, among the old posts and pins,
And Hodge he hied him after till broke were both his shins:
Cursing and swearing oaths, were never of his making,
That Gyb would fire the house, if that she were not taken.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: See here is all the thought that the foolish Urchin taketh,
And Tyb methink at his elbow almost as merry maketh
This is all the wit ye have when others make their moan,
Come down Hodge, where art thou and let the Cat alone.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Gog's heart, help and come up, Gyb in her tail hath fire.
And is like to burn all if she get a little hire:
Come down quoth you, nay then you might count me a patch,
The house cometh down on your heads if it take once the thatch.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: It is the cats eyes fool that shineth in the dark.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Hath the Cat do you think in every eye a spark.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: No, but they shine as like fire as ever man see.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: By the mass and she burn all, you shall bear the blame for me

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Come down and help to seek here our needle that it were found
Down Tyb on thy knees I say, down Cocke to the ground.
To God I make a vow, and so to good Saint Anne
A candle shall they have a piece, get it where I can,
If I may my needle find in one place or in other.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Now a vengeance on gib light, on gyb and gybs mother
And all the generation of Cats both far and near
Look on the ground whoreson think thou the needle is here.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: By my troth gammer methought your needle here I saw
But when my fingers touched it, I felt it was a straw.

sp.speaker: Tyb
sp.l: See Hodge what is this, may it not be within it,

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Break it fool with thy hand and see if thou canst find it.

sp.speaker: Tyb
sp.l: Nay break it you Hodge according to your word.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Gog's sides, fie it stinks: it is a Cats turd,
It were well done to make thee eat it by the mass.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: This matter amendeth not my needle is still where it was
Our candle is at an end let us all in quiet
And come another time, when we have more light
Back and side go bare, go bare,
Booth foot and hand go cold:
But Belly god send thee good ale enough ,
Whether it be new or old.
I cannot eat, but little meat,
My stomach is not good:
But sure I think, that I can drink
With him that wears a hood.
Though I go bare, take ye no care,
I am nothing a cold:
I stuffed my skin, so full within,
Of jolly good Ale and old.
Back and side go bare, go bare,
Booth foot and hand go cold:
But belly god send the good ale enough
Whether it be new or old.
I love no roast, but a nut brown toast
And a Crab laid in the fire,
A little bread, shall do me stead
Much bread I not desire:
No frost nor snow, no wind I trow
Can hurt me if I would ,
I am so wrapped, and thoroughly lapped
Of jolly good ale and old.
Back and side go bare. etcetera
And Tyb my wife, that as her life
Loveth well good ale to seek,
Full oft drinks she, till ye may see
The tears run down her cheeks:
Then doth she troll, to me the bowl
even as a malt worm should ,
And sayeth sweet heart, I took my part
Of this jolly good ale and old.
Back and side go bare. etcetera
Now let them drink, till they nod and wink,
Even as good fellows should do
They shall not miss, to have the bliss,
Good ale doth bring men to:
And all poor souls that have scoured bowls
Or have them lustily trolled,
God save the lives, of them and their wives
Whether they be young or old.
Back and side go bare. etcetera

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Well done by Gog's malt, well sung and well said,
Come on mother Chat as thou art true maid,
One fresh pot of ale let us see to make an end
Against this cold weather, my naked arms to defend,
This gear it warms the soul, now wind blow on the worst,
And let us drink and swill, till that our bellies burst
Now were he a wise man, by cunning cold define
Which way my Journey lieth or where Dyccon will dine
But one good turn I have, be it by night or day
South, East, North or west, I am never out of my way.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I am goodly rewarded, I am I not, do you think?
I had a goodly dinner for all my sweat and swink,
Neither butter cheese, milk onions flesh nor fiche
Save this poor piece of barley bread, it is a pleasant costly dish.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Hail fellow Hodge and will to fare, with thy meat, if you have any?
But by thy words as I the smelled, thy daintrels be not many .

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Daintrels dicco gog's soul man save this piece of dry horsebread,
I have bit no bit this live long day, no crone come in my head
My guts they yawl crawl and all my belly rumbleth
The puddings cannot lie still, each one over other tumbleth
By gog's heart I am so vexed, and in my belly pent
I would one piece were at the spittlehouse another at the castle's end.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Why hodge, was there none at home thy dinner for to set:

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Gog's bread Diccon I came too late, was nothing there to get
Gib a foul fiend might on her light licked the milk pan so clean
See Diccon, it was not so well washed this seven year as I wean
A pestilence light on all ill luck, I had thought yet for all this
Of a morsel of bacon behind the door at worst should not miss,
But when I sought a slip to cut, as I was wont to do
Gog's soul Diccon, gyb our Cat had eat the bacon too .
Which bacon Diccon stole, as is declared before.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Ill luck quoth he, marry swear it hodg, this day the truth to tell
Thou rose not on thy right side, or else blessed thee not well,
Thy milk slopped up, thy bacon filched, that was too bad luck hodg.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Nay, nay, there was a fowler fault, my gamer gave me the dodge
Seest not how I am rent and torn, my heels, my knees and my breech
I had thought as I sat by the fire, help here and there a stitch,
But there I was pooped indeed .

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Why Hodge?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Boots not man to tell,
I am so dressed amongst a sort of fools, I had better be in hell,
My gammer ( I am ashamed to say) by god served me not well

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: How so Hodge?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Has she not gone trowest now and lost her needle.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Her Eel Hodge, who fished of late? that was a dainty dish.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Tush tush, her needle, her needle, her needle man, it is neither flesh nor fish.
A little thing with an hole in the end, as bright as any silver,
Small, long, sharpe at the point, and straight as any pillar.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: I know not what a devil you meanest, you bringest me more in doubt

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Knowest not with what tom tailors man, sits broaching through a clout
A needle, needle, a needle, my gammers needle is gone.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Her needle Hodge, now I smell thee, that was a chance alone,
By the mass you hadst a shameful loss, and it were but for thy breeches

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Gog's soul man I would give a crown I had it but three stitches.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: How sayst you Hodg, what should he have, again thy needle got

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Bem fathers soul, if I had it I would give him a new grot.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Canst thou keep counsel in this case.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Else I would my thong were out.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Do thou but then by my advice, and I will fetch it with out doubt,

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I will run, I will ride, I will dig, I will delve, I will toil, I will trudge shalt see:
I will hold I will draw, I will pull, I will pinch I will kneel on my bare knee.
I will scrape, I will scratch, I will sift, I will seek, I will bow, I will bend, I will sweat,
I will stoop, I will stir, I will cap I will kneel, I will crepe on hands and feet,
I will be thy bondman Diccon, I swear by sun and moon
And I cannot sum what to stop this gap, I am utterly undone

body.stage: Pointing behind to his torne kreeches.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Why, is there any special cause, thou takest hereat such sorrow

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Kirstian Clack Tom simsons maid, by the mass comes hither tomorrow
I am not able to say, between us what may hap,
She smiled on me the last sunday when I put off my cap,

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Well Hodge this is a matter of weight, and must be kept close,
It might else turn to both our costs as the world now goes,
Shalt swear to be no blab Hodge.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I will Diccon.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Then go to,
Lay thine hand here, say after me as thou shalt here me do
Hast no book?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I have no book I.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Then needs must force us both,
Upon my breech to lay thine hand, and there to take thine oath.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I Hodge breech-less,
Swear to Diccon reachless
By the cross that I shall kiss,
To keep his counsel close
And always me to dispose
To work that his pleasure is.
Here he kisses Diccons breech.

sp.speaker: Diccon.
sp.l: Now Hodge see thou take heed
And do as I thee bid
For so I judge it meet,
This needle again to win
There is no shift therein
But conjure up a spirit.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: What the great devil Diccon I say?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Yea in good faith, that is the way,
Fetch with some pretty charm.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Soft Diccon be not too hasty yet,
By the mass for I begin to sweat
I am afraid of some harm.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Come hither then and stir thee not
One inch out of this Circle plait
But stand as I thee teach.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: And shall I be here safe from their claws:

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: The master devil with his long paws
Here to thee cannot reach:
Now will I settle me to this gear.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I say Diccon, hear me, hear:
Go softly to this matter.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: What devil man, art afraid of naught

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Canst not tarry a little thought
Till I make a courtesy of water.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Stand still to it, why shouldst thou fear him ?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Gog's sides Diccon, methink I hear him
And tarry I shall mare all.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: The matter is no worse than I told it,

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: By the mass I am able no longer to hold it,
Too bad I must bewray the hall.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Stand to it Hodge, stir not you whoreson,
What Devil, be thine arse strings burst?
Thyself a while but staye,
The devil I smell him will be here anon.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Hold him fast Diccon, I am gone, I am gone
I will not be at that fray.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Fie shitten knave, and out upon thee
Above all other louts fie on thee,
Is not here a cleanly prank?
But thy matter was no better
Nor thy presence here no sweater,
To fly I can thee thank:
Here is a matter worthy glossing
Of Gammer Gurtons needle losing
And a foul piece of work,
A man I think might make a play
And need no word to this they say
Being but half a Clarke.
Soft, let me alone, I will take the charge
This matter further to enlarge
Within a time short,
If ye will mark my toys, and note
I will give ye leave to cut my throat
If I make not good sport,
Dame Chat I say, where be ye, within?

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Who have we there maketh such a din:

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Here is a good fellow, maketh no great danger,

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: What diccon? come near, ye be no stranger,
We be fast set at trump man, hard by the fire,
Thou shalt set on the king, if thou come a little nigher.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Nay, nay, there is no tarrying: I must be gone again
But first for you in council I have a word or twain.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Come hither Dol, Dol, sit down and play this game,
And as thou sawest me do, see thou do even the same
There is 5. trumps beside the Queen, the hindmost you shalt find her
Take heed of Sim glovers wife, she hath an eye behind her,
Now Diccon say your will.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Nay soft a little yet,
I would not tell it my sister, the matter is so great,
There I will have you swear by our dear Lady of Bullaine,
Saint Dunstone, and Saint Donnyke, with the three Kings of Kullaine,
That ye shall keep it secret.

sp.speaker: Chat,
sp.l: Gog's bread that will I do,
As secret as mine own thought, by god and the devil too .

sp.speaker: Diccon.
sp.l: Here is gamer gurton your neighbour, a sad and heavy wight
Her goodly fair red Cock, at home was stole this last night.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Gog's soul her Cock with the yellow legs, that nightly crowed so just?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: That cocke is stolen.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: What was he fetch out of the hens rust?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: I cannot tell where the devil he was kept, under key or lock,
But Tib hath tickled in Gammers ear, that you should steal the cocke

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Have I strong whore? by bread and salt.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: What soft, I say be still .
Say not one word for all this gear.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: By the mass that I will ,
I will have the young whore by the head, and the old trot by the throat

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Not one word dame Chat I say, not one word for my cote.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Shall such a beggars brawl as that thinkest you make me a thief
The pocks light on her whores sides, a pestilence and a mischief
Come out thou hungry needy bitch, O that my nails be short.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Gog's bred woman hold your peace, this gear will else pass sport
I would not for an hundred pound, this matter should be known,
That I am author of this tale, or have abroad it blown
Did ye not swear ye would be ruled, before the tale I told
I said ye must all secret keep, and ye said sure ye would .

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Would you suffer yourself diccon, such a sort, to revile you
With slanderous words to blot your name, and so to defile you?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: No goodwife chat I would be loath such drabs should blot my name
But yet ye must so order all, that Diccon bear no blame.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: Go to then, what is your read: say on your mind, ye shall me rule herein.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: God-a-mercy to dame chat, in faith thou must the gear begin
It is twenty pound to a goose turd, my gammer will not tarry
But hitherward she comes as fast as her legs can her carry,
To brawl with you about her cocke, for well I hard Tib say
The Cocke was roasted in your house, to breakfast yesterday,
And when ye had the carcass eaten, the feathers ye out flung
And Doll your maid the legs she hid a foot deep in the dung.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: O gracious god my heart is bursts,

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Well rule yourself a space
And gammer gurton when she cometh anon into this place
Then to the Queen let us see tell her your mind and spare not
So shall Diccon blameless be, and then go to I care not.

sp.speaker: Chat,
sp.l: Then whore beware her throat, I can abide no longer
In faith old witch it shall be seen, which of us two be stronger
And Diccon but at your request, I would not stay one hour,

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Well keep it in till she be here, and then out let it pour,
In the mean while get you in, and make no words of this
More of this matter with in this hour to hear you shall not miss
Because I know you are my friend, hide it I could not doubtless
Ye know your harm, see ye be wise about your own business
So fare ye well .

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Nay soft Diccon and drink, what Doll I say
Bring here a cup of the best ale, let us see, come quickly a way.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Ye see masters the one end tapped of this my short devise
Now must we breche the other too , before the smoke arise
And by the time they have a while run. I trust ye need not crave it.
But look what lieth in both their hearts ye are like sure to have it

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Yea gog's soul, art alive yet? what Diccon dare I come?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: A man is well hied to trust to thee, I will say nothing but mum
But if ye come any nearer I pray you see all be sweet.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Tush man, is gammers needle found, that I would gladly weet

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: She may thank thee it is not found, for if you had kept thy stading
The devil he would have fetch it out, even hodg at thy commanding

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Gog's heart, and could he tell nothing where the needle might be found

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Ye foolish dolt, ye were to seek, ere we had got our ground,
Therefore his tale so doubtful was, that I could not perceive it.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Then I se well something was said, I hope one day yet to have it,
But diccon, diccon, did not the devil cry ho, ho, ho,

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: If you hadst tarried where thou stoodest, thou wouldst have said so

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Durst swear of a book, I heard him roar, straight after I was gone
But tell me diccon what said the knave: let me hear it anon.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: The whoreson talked to me. I know not well of what
One while his tongue it ran and paltered of a Cat,
Another while he stammered still still upon a Rat,
Last of all there was nothing but every word Chat, Chat,
But this I well perceived before I would him rid,
Between Chat, and the Rat, and the Cat, the needle is hid,
Now whether Gyb our cat have eat it in her maw,
Or Doctor Rat our curate have found it in the straw,
Or this dame chat your neighbour have stolen it, god he knoweth
But by the morrow at this time, we shall learn how the matter goeth

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Canst not learn tonight man, seest not what is here,

body.stage: Pointyng behind to his torne breeches.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: It is not possible to make it sooner appear,

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Alas Diccon then I have no shift, but lest ich tarry too long
Hie me to Sym glovers shop, there to seek for a Thong,
There with this breech to tatch and tie as I may.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Tomorrow hodg if we chance to meet, shalt see what I will say.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Now this gear must forward go, for here my gammer: cometh,
Be still a while and say nothing, make here a little romth.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Good lord, shall never be my luck my needle again to spy?
Alas the while it is past my help, where it is still it must lie.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Now Iesus gammer gurton, what driveth you to this sadness:
I fear me by my conscience, you will sure fall to madness.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Who is that, what Diccon, I am lost man: fie fie.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Marry fie on them that be worthy, but what should be your trouble,

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Alas the more I think on it, my sorrow it waxeth double
My goodly tossing sporyars needle, I have lost I wot not where.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Your needle, when?

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: My needle (alas) I might full ill it spare,
As god himself he knoweth never one beside I have .

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: If this be all good gammer, I warrant you all is save.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Why know you any tidings which way my needle is gone?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Yea that I do doubtless, as ye shall hear anon,
I see a thing this matter toucheth, within these xx. hours,
Even at this gate, before my face, by a neighbour of yours,
She stooped me down, and up she toke a needle or a pin:
I durst be sworn it was even yours, by all my mothers kin.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: It was my needle diccon I wot, for here even by this post
I sat, what time as I up start, and so my needle it lost:
Who was it lieve son? speak I pray thee , and quickly tell me that?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: A subtle quean as any in this Town, your neighbour here dame Chat.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Dame chat diccon let me be gone, I will thither in post haste.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Take my council yet or ye go, for fear ye walk in waste ,
It is a murrion crafty drab, and froward to be pleased,
If ye take not the better way, our needle yet ye lose it:
For when she took it up, even here before your doors
What soft dame chat (quoth I) that same is none of yours
Avaunt (quoth she) sir knave, what pratest thou of that I find:
I would you hadst kissed me I wot where : (she meant I know behind)
And home she went as brag, as it had been a body-louse,
And I after as bold, as it had been, the goodman of the house:
But there and ye had hard her, how she began to scold
The tongue it went on patens, by him that Iudas sold,
Each other word I was a knave, and you a whore of whores,
Because I spake in your behalf, and said the needle was yours.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Gog's bread, and thinks the callet thus to keep my needle me from?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Let her alone, and she minds non other but even to dress you so

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: By the mass I will rather spend the cote that is on my back.
Thinks the false quean by such a slygh, that I will my needle lack

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Sleep not you gear I counsel you, but of this take good heed
Let not be known I told you of it, how well soever ye speed.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: I will in Diccon a clean apron to take, and set before me,
And I may my needle once see, I will sure remember thee

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Here will the sport begin, if these two once may meet.
Their cheer durst lay money will prove scarcely sweet
My gammer sure intends, to be upon her bones,
With staves, or with clubs, or else with cobble stones.
Dame Chat on the other side, if she be far behind
I am right far deceived she is given to it of kind,
He that may tarry by it a while , and that but short
I warrant him trust to it, he shall see all the sport
Into the town will I, my friends to visit there
And hither straight again to see the end of this gear
In the mean time fellows, pipe up your fiddles, I say take them
And let your friends hear such mirth as ye can make them.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Sym glover yet gramercy, I am meetly well sped now,
Thou art even as good a fellow as ever kissed a cow,
Here is a thing in deed, by the mass though I speak it
Tom tankards great bald curtal, I think could not break it
And when he spied my need, to be so straight and hard,
Has lent me here his nail, to set the gyb forward,
As for my Gammers needle, the flying feud go weet,
I will not now go to the door again with it to meet:
I would make shift good enough if I had a candles end,
The chief hole in my breech, with these two I will amend.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: How Hodge, mayst now be glade, I have news to tell thee
I know who has my needle, I trust soon shalt it see

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: The devil thou does, hast hard gammer in deed, or dost but jest

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: It is as true as steel Hodge.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Why, knowest well where didst leese it?

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: I know who found it, and took it up shalt see or it be long .

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Gods mother dear, if that be true, farewell both nail an thong
But who has it gammer say on: I would fain hear it disclosed.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: That false vixen, that same dame Chat, that counts herself so honest.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Who told you so:

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: That same did Diccon the bedlam, which saw it done.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Diccon: it is a vengeable knave gammer, it is a bonable whoreson,
Can do more things than that else I am deceived evil:
By the mass I saw him of late call up a great black devil,
O the knave cried ho, ho, he roared and he thundered,
If you had been here, I am sure you would murrenly have wondered.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Was not thou afraid Hodge to see him in this place:

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: No, if he had come to me, I would have laid him on the face,
I would have promised him.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: But Hodge, had he no horns to push:

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: As long as your two arms, saw ye never Fryer Rush
Painted on a cloth, with a side long cow's tail:
And crooked cloven feet, and many a hooked nail?
For all the world (if I should judge) I would reckon him his brother
Look even what face Friar Rush had, the devil had such another

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: New Iesus mercy hodg, did diccon in him bring:

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Nay gammer (hear me speak) I will tell you a greater thing.
The devil (when diccon had him, I hard him wondrous well )
Said plainly here before us, that dame chat had your needle.

sp.speaker: mer
sp.l: Then let us go, and ask her wherefore she minds to keep it,
Seeing we know so much, it were a madness now to sleep it.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Go to her gamer see ye not where she stands in her doors
Bid her give you the needle, it is none of hers but yours.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Dame Chat I would pray thee fair, let me have that is mine
I will not this twenty years take one fart that is thine
Therefore give me mine own and let me live beside thee

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Why art thou crept from home hither , to mine own doors to chide me:
Hence doting drab, avaunt, or I shall set thee further.
Intends thou and that knave, me in my house to murther:

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Tush gape not so no me woman, shalt not yet eat me,
Nor all the friends thou hast, in this shall not entreat me:
Mine own goods I will have, and ask thee on believe,
What woman: pore folks must have right, though the thing you agrieve.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Give thee thy right, and hang thee up , with all thy beggar's brood
What wilt thou make me a thief, and say I stole thy good:

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: I will say nothing I warrant thee, but that I can prove it well
Thou set my good even from my door, I am able this to tell,

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Did I (old witch) steal oft was thine: how should that thing be known:

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: I cannot tell, but up thou tookest it as though it had been thine own,

sp.speaker: Chat,
sp.l: Marry fie on thee, thou old gyb, with all my very heart.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Nay fie on thee you ramp, thou rig, with all that take thy part.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: A vengeance on those lips that laieth such things to my charge.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: A vengeance on those callet's hips, whose conscience is so large

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Come out Hogge.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Come out hogge, and let have me right.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Thou arrant Witch.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Thou bawdy bitch, I will make thee curse this night.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: A bag and a wallet.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: A cart for a callet.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Why weenest thou thus to prevail,
I hold thee a groat,
I shall patch thy coat,

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Thou wert as good kiss my tail:
Thou slut you kut, you rakes, you jakes: will not shame make ye hide

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Thou scald, thou bald, thou rotten, you glutton, I will no longer chid the
But I will teach thee to keep home.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Wilt thou drunken beast.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Stick to her gammer, take her by the head, I will warrant you this feast.
Smite I say gammer,
Byte I say gammer,
I trow ye will be keen:
Where be your nails? claw her by the jaws, pull me out both her eyen,
Gog's bones gammer, hold up your head,

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: I trow drab I shall dress thee.
Tarry you knave I hold thee a groat, I shall make these hands bless thee
Take you this old whore for amends , and learn thy tongue well to tame
And say thou met at this bickering, not thy fellow but thy dame.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Where is the strong stewed whore, I will gear a whores mark,
Stand out ones way, that I kill none in the dark:
Up gammer if ye be alive, I will feygh now for us both,
Come no near me thou scald callet, to kill thee I were loath.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Art here again thou hoddy peke, what doll bring me out my spit.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I will broach thee with this, him father soul, I will conjure that foul spirit:
Let door stand Cock, why come in deed? keep door you whoreson boy.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Stand to it you dastard for thine ears, I shall tech it a sluttish toy.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Gog's wounds whore, I will make thee avaunt, take heed Cocke, pull in the latch,

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: I'faith sir loose breech had ye tarried, ye should have found your match.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Now ware thy throat losel, thou shalt pray for all

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Well said gammer by my soul,
Hoise her, souse her, bounce her, trounce her, pull out her throat bowl

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Comest behind me thou withered witch, and I get once on foot
Thou shalt pay for all, you old tar-leather, I will teach thee what longs to it
Take ye this to make up thy mouth, till time thou come by more

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Up gammer stand on your feet, where is the old whore?
Faith would I had her by the face I would crack her callet crown

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: A hodg, hodg, where was thy help, when vixen had me down .

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: By the mass Gammer, but for my staff Chat had gone nigh to spy you
I think the harlot had not cared, if I had not come to kill you
But shall we lose our needle thus?

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: No Hodge I were loathe do so,
Thinkest thou I will take that at her hand, no hodg I tell thee no

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I would yet this fray were well take up, and our own needle at home
It will be my chance else some to kill, where ever it be or whom

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: We have a parson, (hodge thou knows) a man esteemed wise
Mast doctor Rat, I will for him send, and let me hear his advice,
He will her shrive for all this gear, and give her penance strait
We shall have our needle, else dame chat comes never within heaven gate,

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Ye marry gammer, that I think best: will you now for him lend
The sooner Doctor Rat be here, the sooner we shall have an end,
And here gammer Dyccons devil, (as I remember well)
Of Cat, and Chat, and Doctor Rat: a felonious tale did tell,
I hold you forty pound, that is the way your needle to get again.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: I will have him strait, call out the boy, we shall make him take the pain

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: What coke I say, come out what devil canst not hear .
How now hodg? how does gammer, is yet the weather clear?
What would she have me to do?

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Come hither Cocke anon:
Hence swythe to Doctor Rat, hie thee that thou were gone,
And pray him come speak with me, I am not well at ease,
Shalt have him at his chamber, of else at mother Bees,
Else seek him at Hobfylchers shop, for as I heard it reported
There is the best ale in all the town, and now is most resorted.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: And shall I bring him with me gammer?

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Yea, by and by good Cocke.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: Shalt see that shall be here anon, else let me have one the dock

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Now gammer shall we two go in, and tarry for his coming
What devil woman pluck up your heart , and leave off all this gloaming
Though she were stronger at the first, as I think ye did find her
Yet there ye dressed the drunk sow, what time ye cam behind her

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Nay, nay, I am sure she lost not all, for set the end to the beginning
And I doubt not, but she will make small boast of her winning.

sp.speaker: Tyb
sp.l: Se gamer, gamer, gib our cat, I am afraid what she aileth
She stands me gasping behind the door, as though her wind her faileth:
Now let I doubt what gib should mean, that now she doth so dote.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Hold hither, I hold twenty pound, your needle is in her throat
Grope her I say, methinks I feele it, does not prick your hand?

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: I can feele nothing.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: No, I know there is not within this land
A muryner Cat than Gyb is, betwixt the Thames and Tyne,
She has as much wit in her head almost as I have in mine.

sp.speaker: Tyb
sp.l: Faith she has eaten some thing, that will not easily down
Whether she got it at home, or abroad in the town
I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Alas I fear it he some croked pin,
And then farewell gyb, she is undone, and lost all save the skin.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Tyb, your needle woman, I say: gog's soul give me a knife
And I will have it out of her maw, or else I shall lose my life.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: What nay hodg, fie kill not our cat, it is all the cats we have now.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: By the mass dame Chat has me so moved, I care not what I kill, ma god a vow:
Go to then Tyb to this gear, hold up her tail and take her,
I will see what devil is in her guts, I will take you the pains to rake her.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Rake a Cat Hodge, what wouldst thou do?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: What thinkest that I am not able?
Did not Tom Tankard rake his Curtal tother day standing in the stable.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Soft be content, let us hear what news Cocke bringeth from master Rat.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: Gammer I have been there as you bad, you wot well about what
It will not be long before he come, I durst swear of a book
He bids you see ye be at home, and there for him to look .

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Where didst thou find him boy was he not where I told thee?

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: Yes, yes even at hobfilchers house, by him that bought and sold me
A cup of ale had in his hand, and a crab lay in the fire,
I had much a do to go and come, all was so full of mire:
And Gammer one thing I can tell, Hobfilchers nail was lost
And Doctor Rat found it again, hard beside the door post,
I I hold a penny can say something, your needle again to fetch.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: I am glad to hear so much Cocke, then trust he will not let,
to help us herein best he can therefore till time he come
Let us go in if there be aught to get thou shalt have some.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: A Man were better twenty times be a bandog and bark.
Than here among such a sort, be parish priest or clarke
Where he shall never be at rest, one pissing while a day
But he must trudge about the town, this way, and that way,
Here to a drab, there to a thief, his shoes to tear and rent
And that which is worst of all, at every knaves commandment
I had not sit the space, to drink two pots of ale
But Gammer gurtons sorry boy, was straight way at my tail,
And she was sick, and I must come, to do I wot not what,
If once her fingers end but ache, trudge, call for Doctor Rat
And when I come not at their call, I only thereby lose,
For I am sure to lack therefore, a tithe pig or a goose:
I warrant you when truth is known, and told they have their tale
The matter where about I come, is not worth a half penny worth of ale,
Yet must I talk so sage and smooth, as though I were a glossier
Else or the year come at an end. I shall be sure the loser.
What work ye gammer gurton? how here is your friend Master. Rat.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Ah good Master. Doctor I have troubled, I have troubled you, I know well that

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: How do ye woman: be ye lusty, or be ye not well at ease:

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: By gys master I am not such, but yet I have a disease.
I had a foul turn now of late, I will tell it you by gigs.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Hath your brown cow cast her calf, or your sandy sow her pigs

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: No, but I had been as good they had, as this I wot well .

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Alas, alas, I have lost my good needle,
My needle I say, and wot ye what: a drab came by and spied it
And when I asked her for the same, the filth flatly denied it.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: What was she that:

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: A dame I warrant you: she began to scold and brawl
Alas, alas, come hither Hodge: this wretch can tell you all.

body.stage: Hodge Doctor Rat. Gammer. Diccon. Chat.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: God morrow gaffer Vicar

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Come on fellow let us hear .
Thy dame hath said to me, thou knowest of all this gear,
Let us see what thou canst say .

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: By my fay sir that ye shall,
What matter so ever here was done, I can tell your mastership
My Gammer gurton here see now,
Sat her down at this door, see now:
And as she began to stir her, see now,
Her needle fell in the floor, see now,
And while her staff she took , see now,
At Gyb her Cat to fling, see now,
Her needle was lost in the floor, see now
Is not this a wondrous thing, see now?
Then came the quean Dame Chat, see now
To ask for her black cup, see now:
And even here at this gate, see now:
She took that needle up, see now:
My Gammer then she yeede, see now
Her needle again to bring, see now
And was caught by the head see now
Is not this a wondrous thing, see now
She tare my Gammers cote see now
And scratched her by the face, see now
I had thought she had stopped her throat, see now
Is not this a wondrous case, see now?
When I saw this, I was worth see now
And start between them twain, see now
Else I durst take a book oath, see now
My Gammer had been slain, see now.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: This is even the whole matter, as Hodge has plainly told
And I would fain be quiet for my part, that I would
But help us good master, beseech ye that ye do
Else shall we both be beaten and lose our needle too.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: What would ye have me to do? tell me that I were gone
I will do the best that I can, to set you both at one
But be ye sure dame Chat hath this your needle found:

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Here comes the man that see her take it up off the ground,
Ask him yourself master Rat if ye believe not me.
And help me to my needle, for gods sake and saint charity.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Come near diccon and let us hear, what thou can express.
Wilt you be sworn you seest dame chat, this woman's needle have?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Nay by Saint Benit will I not, then might ye think me rave.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Why didst not you tell me so even here canst you for shame deny it

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Aye marry gammer: but I said I would not abide by it,

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Will you say a thing, and not stick to it to try it?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Stick to it quoth you master rat, marry sir I defy it,
Nay there is many an honest man, when he such blasts hath blown
In his friends ears, he would be loath the same by him were known
If such a toy be used oft among the honesty
It may be seem a simple man, if your and my degree

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Then we be never the nearer, for all that you can tell.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Yes marry sir, if ye will do by mine advice and counsel,
If mother chat se all us here, she knoweth how the matter goes
Therefore I red you three go hence, and within keep close,
And I will into dame chats house, and so the matter use,
That or you could go twice to church, I warrant you hear news,
She shall look well about her, but I durst lay a pledge,
Ye shall of gammers needle, have shortly better knowledge.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Now gentle Diccon do so, and good sir let us trudge.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: By the mass I may not tarry so long to be your judge.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: It is but a little while man, what take so much pain,
If I hear no news of it, I will come sooner again.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Tarry so much, good master Doctor of your gentleness.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Then let us hie us inward, and Diccon speed thy business.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Now sirs do you no more, but keep my counsel just,
And Doctor Rat shall thus catch, some good I trust,
But mother Chat my gossip, talk first with all I must:
For she must be chief captain to lay the Rat in the dust,
God divine dame Chat in faith, and well met in this place.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: God divine my friend Diccon, whether walk ye this pace?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: By my truth even to you, to learn how the world goeth,
Hard ye no more of the other matter, say me now by your troth

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: O yes diccon, here the old whore, and hodge that great knave.
But in faith I would thou hadst seen, o lord I dressed them brave
She bare me two or three souses behind in the nape of the neck
Till I made her old wesen, to answer again kecke:
And Hodge that dirty dastard, that at her elbow stands,
If one pair of legs had not been worth two pair of hands
He had had his beard shaven, if my nails would have served
And not without a cause, for the knave it well deserved.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: By the mass I can thee thank wench, you didst so well acquit thee

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: If thou hadst seen him Diccon, it would have made ye beshite thee
For laughter. The whoreson dolt at last caught up a club,
As though he would have slain the master devil Beelzebub,
But I set him soon inward.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: O Lord there is the thing
That Hodge is so offended, that makes him start and fling

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Why? makes the knave any moiling, as ye have seen or hard

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Even now I saw him last, like a mad man he fared,
And swear by heaven and hell, he would a wreak his sorrow
And leave you never a hen on live. by eight of the clock tomorrow ,
Therefore mark what I say, and my words see that ye trust
Your hens be as good as dead, if ye leave them on the rust.

sp.speaker: Chat,
sp.l: The knave dare as well go hang himself, as go upon my ground

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Well yet take heed I say, I must tell you my tale round,
Have you not about your house, behind your furnace or lead:
A hole where a crafty knave, may crepe in for need?

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Yes by the mass, a hole broke down, even w within these two days.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Hodge, he intends this same night, to slip in there aways.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: O christ that I were sure of it, in faith he should have his meed.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Watch well, for the knave will be there as sure as is your creed
I would spend myself a shilling: to have him swinged well.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: I am as glad as a woman can be. of this thing to hear tell
By gog's bones when he cometh, now that I know the matter
He shall sure at the first skip, to leap in scalding water:
With a worse turn besides, when he will, let him come.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: I tell you as my sister, you know what meaneth mum,
Now lack I but my doctor, to play his part again
And lo where he cometh towards, peradventure to his pain.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: What good news Diccon? fellow, is mother chat at home,

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: She is sir, and she is not, but it please her to whom:
Yet did I take her tardy, as subtle as she was.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: The thing that thou wentest for, haste thou brought it to pass?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: I have done that I have done, be it worse, be it better.
And dame Chat at her wits end, I have almost set her.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Why hast thou spied the needle quickly I pray thee tell.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: I have spied it in faith sir, I handled myself so well,
And yet the crafty quean, had almost take my trump.
But or all came to an end, I set her in a dump:

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: How so I pray thee Diccon?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Marry sir will ye hear?
She was clapped down on the backside, by cocks mother dear
And there she sat sewing a halter, or a band,
With no other thing save gammers needle in her hand,
As soon as any knock, if the filth be in doubt,
She needs but once puff, and her candle is out:
Now I sir knowing of every door the pin.
Came nicely, and said no word, till time I was within,
And there I saw the needle, even with these two eyes,
Who ever say the contrary, I will swear he lies.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: O Diccon that I was not there, then in thy stead.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Well, if ye will be ordered, and do by my read.
I will bring you to a place, as the house stands.
Where ye shall take the drab, with the needle in her hands

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: For Gods sake do so Diccon, and I will gage my gown
To give thee a full pot, of the best ale in the town,

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Follow me but a little, and mark what I will say,
Lay down your gown beside you, go to, come on your way:
Se ye not what is here? a hole wherein ye may creep
Into the house, and suddenly unawares among them leap,
There shall ye find the Bitchfox, and the needle together
Do as I bid you man, come on your ways hither .

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Art thou sure diccon, the swill tub stands not hereabout.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: I was within myself man even now, there is no doubt,
Go softly, make no noise, give me your foot sir Iohn,
Here will I wait upon you, till you come out anon.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Help Diccon, out alas, I shall be slain among them.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: If they give you not the needle, tell them that ye will hag them
Ware that, how my wenches, have ye caught the Fox,
That used to make revel, among your hens and Cocks:
Save his life yet for his order, though he sustain some pain
Gog's bread, I am afraid, they will beat out his brain.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Woe worth the hour that I came here.
And woe worth him that wrought this gear,
A sort of drabs and queans have me blessed,
Was ever creature half so evil dressed?
Who ever it wrought, and first did invent it,
He shall I warrant him, ere long repent it,
I will spend all I have without my skin
But he shall be brought to the plight I am in,
Master Bayly I trow, and he be worth his ears.
Will snaffle these murderers and all that them bears,
I will surely neither byte nor sup
Till I fetch him hither, this matter to take up.

sp.speaker: Bailie.
sp.l: I Can perceive none other, I speak it from my heart
But either ye are in all the fault or else in the greatest part

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: If it be counted his fault, besides all his grieves
When a poor man is spoiled: and beaten among thieves?
Then I confess my fault herein, at this season,
But I hope you will not judge so much against reason.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: And methinks by your own tale, of all that ye name.
If any played the thief you were the very same.
The women they did nothing, as your words make probation
But stoutly withstood your forcible invasion,
If that a thief at your window, to enter should begin,
Would you hold forth your hand, and help to pull him in:
Or you would keep him out: I pray you answer me.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Marry keep him out, and a good cause why:
But I am no thief sir but an honest learned Clarke.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Yea but who knoweth that, when he meets you in the dark
I am sure your learning shines not out at your nose,
Was it any marvel, though the poor woman arose
And start up, being afraid of that was in her purse
Methink you may be glad that you luck was no worse.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Is not this evil enough, I pray you as you think,

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Yea but a man in the dark, of chances do wink,
As soon he smites his father, as any other man,
Because for lack of light, discern him he ne can.
Might it not have been your luck, with a spit to have been slain:

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: I think I am little better, my scalp is cloven to the brain,
If there be all the remedy, I know who bears the knocks.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: By my troth and well worthy, besides to kiss the stocks
To come in on the back side, when ye might go about,
I know non such, unless they long to have their brains knocked out

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Well, will you be so good sir, as talk with dame Chat?
And know what she intended: I ask no more but that.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Let her be called fellow because of master doctor,
I warrant in this case, she will be her own Proctor,
She will tell her own tale in metre or in prose,
And bid you seek your remedy, and so go wipe your nose.

body.stage: M.Bayly. Chat. D.Rat. Gammer. Hodge. Diccon.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Dame Chat, master doctor upon you here complained
That you and your maids should him much misorder.
And taketh many an oath, that no word he fained,
Laying to your charge, how you thought him to murder:
And on his part again, that same man saith further
He never offended you in word nor intent,
To bear you answer hereto, we have now for you sent.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: That I would have murdered him, fie on him wretch,
And evil mought be thee for it, our Lord I beseech.
I will swear on all the books that opens and shuts
He faineth this tale out of his own guts,
For this seven weeks with me, I am sure he sat not down ,
Nay ye have other minions, in the other end of the town,
Where ye were liker to catch such a blow,
Than any where else, as far as I know.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Be like then master Doctor, you stripe there ye got not?

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Think you I am so mad, that where I was bet, I wot not?
Will ye believe this quean, before she hath tried it?
It is not the first deed she hath done and afterward denied it.

sp.speaker: Chat
sp.l: What man, will you say I broke your head?

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: How canst thou prove the contrary?

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Nay, how provest thou that I did the deed.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Too plainly, by Saint Marry.
This proof I trow may serve, though I no word spoke.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Because thy head is broken, was it I that it broke?
I saw thee Rat I tell thee, not once within this fortnight,

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: No marry, thou sawest me not, for why thou hadst no light,
But I felt thee for all the dark, beshrew thy smooth cheeks,
And thou groped me, this will declare, any day this six weeks

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Answer me to this Master Rat, when caught you this harm of yours?

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: A while a go sir, god he knoweth, within les than these two hours.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Dame Chat was there none with you: (confess I'faith) about that season.
What woman, let it be what it will, it is neither felony nor treason

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Yes by my faith master Bayly, there was a knave not far
Who caught one good Philup on the brow, with a door bar
And well was he worthy, as it seemed to me,
But what is that to this man, since this was not he .

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Who was it then? let us hear.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Alas sir, ask you that?
Is it not made plain enough by the own mouth of dame chat
The time agreeth, my head is broken, her tong cannot lie,
Only upon a bare, nay she saith it was not I.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: No marry was it not indeed ye shall hear by this one thing,
This after noon a friend of mine, for good will gave we warning
And bad me well look to my rust, and all my Capons pens,
For if I toke not better heed, a knave would have my hens,
Then I to save my goods, toke so much pains as him to watch
And as good fortune served me, it was my chance him for to catch
What strokes he bare away, or other what was his gains
I wot not, but sure I am, he has something for his pains

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Yet tells thou not who it was.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Who it was a false thief,
That came like a false Fox, my pullain to kill and mischief.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: But knowest thou not his name?

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: I know it but what then ,
It was that crafty cullion Hodge my gammer gurtons man.

sp.speaker: Bailie.
sp.l: Call me the knave hither, he shall sure kiss the stocks.
I shall teach him a lesson, for filching hens or cocks.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: I marvel master bayly, so bleared be your eyes.
An egg is not so full of meat, as she is full of lies:
When she hath played this prank, to excuse all this gear,
She layeth the fault in such a one, as I know was not there.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Was he not there look on his pate, that shall be his witness.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: I would my head were half so hole, I would seek no redress.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: God bless you gammer Gurton.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: God dylde you master mine.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Thou hast a knave within thy house, hodge, a servant of thine.
They tell me that busy knave, is such a filching one,
That Hen, Pig, goose or capon, thy neighbour can have none,

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: By god I am much amoved, to hear any such report:
Hodge was not wont I trow, to have him in that sort.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: A theenisher knave is not on live, more filching, nor more false
Many a truer man than he, has hanged up by the halse.
And thou his dame of all his theft, thou art the sole receiver
For hodge to catch, and thou to keep, I never knew none better

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Sir reverence of your masterdom, and you were out adoor,
I would be so bold for all her brags, to call her arrant whore,
If I knew Hodge so bad as thou , I wish me endless sorrow
And I would not take the pains, to hang him up before tomorrow ?

sp.speaker: Chat,
sp.l: What have I stolen from thee or thine: thou ill-favoured old trot.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: A great deal more by Gods blessed, than I ever by thee got,
That thou knowest well I need not say it.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Stop there I say,
And tell me here I pray you, this matter by the way:
How chance hodge is not here him would I fain have had.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Alas sir, he will be here anon, have be handled too bad.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Master bayly, sir ye be not such a fool well I know,
But ye perceive by this lingering, there is a pad in the straw.
Thinking that Hodg, his head was broke, and that gammer
would not let him come before them.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: I will show you his face, I warrant thee , lo now where he is.

sp.speaker: Bailie.
sp.l: Come on fellow it is told me thou art a shrew iwis,
Thy neighbours hens you takest, and plays the two legged fox
Their chickens and their capons too and now and then their Cocks.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I defy them all that dare it say, I am as true as the best.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Wert not you taken within this hour, in dame chats hens nest?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Taken there? no master I would not dot, for a house full of gold.

sp.speaker: Chat
sp.l: Thou or the devil in thy cote, swear this I dare be bold.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Swear me no swearing quean, the devil he give thee sorrow,
All is not worth a gnat, thou canst swear till tomorrow ,
Where is the harm he hath? show it by gods bread,
Ye beat him with a witness, but the stripes light on my head.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Bet me? gog's blessed body, I would first I trow have burst thee
I think if I had my hands loose callet I would have crust thee .

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Thou shit knave I trow you knowest the full weight of my fist
I am foully deceived, unless thy head and my door bar kissed

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Hold thy chat whore you criest so loved, can no man else be hard

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Well knave, if I had thee alone, I would surely rap thy costard.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Sir answer me to this, is thy head whole or broken?

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Yea master Bayly, blessed be every good token.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Is my head whole? I warrant you, it is neither scurvy nor scald
What you foul beast, does think it is either piled or bald.
Nay I thank god: I will not for all that thou mayst spend
That I had one scab on my arse, as broad as thy fingers end.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Come nearer here.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Yes that I dare.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: By our Lady here is no harm,
Hodges head is hole enough, for all dame Chats charm.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: By gog's blessed, how ever the thing he clocks or smolders,
I know the blows he bare away, either with head or shoulders,
Camest you not knave within this hour, creeping into my pens
And there was caught within my house, groping among my hens.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: A plague both on thy hens and thee, a cart whore, a cart,
I would I were hanged as hie as a tree, if I were as false as you art
Give my gamer again her washital, you stole away in thy lap.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Yea master bailey there is a thing, you know not on may hap
This drab she keeps away my good, the devil he might her snare
I pray you that I might have, a right action on her.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Have I thy good old filth, or any such old sows?
I am as true, I would thou knew, as skin between thy brows

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Many a truer hath be hanged, though you escape the danger

sp.speaker: Chat,
sp.l: Thou shalt answer by gods pity, for this thy foul slander.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Why, what can ye charge her withal? to say so, ye do not well.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Marry a vengeance to her heart, the whore hase stolen my needle.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Thy needle old witch, how so? it were alms thy skull to knock
so didst thou say, the other day, that I had stolen thy Cock
And roasted him to my breakfast, which shall not be forgotten,
The devil pull out thy lying tong, and teeth that be so rotten.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Give me my needle, as for my cocke, I should be very loath
That I would hear tell he should hang, on thy false faith and troth.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Your talk is such, I can scarce learn who should be most in fault

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Yet shall ye find no other wight, save she, by bred and salt

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Keep ye content a while, se that your tongues ye hold,
Methinks you should remember, this is no place to scold,
How knowest thou gamer gurton, dame Chat thy needle had?

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: To name you sir the party, I would not be very glad.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Yea but we must needs hear it, and therefore say it boldly.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Such one as told the tale, full soberly and coldly,
Even he that looked on, will swear on a book:
What time this drunken gossip, my fair long needle up took
Diccon (master) the Bedlam, I am very sure ye know him.

sp.speaker: Bailie.
sp.l: A false knave by Gods pity, ye were but a fool to trow him,
I durst adventure well the price of my best cap,
That when the end is known, all will turn to a jape,
Told he not you that besides, she stole your Cocke that tide?

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: No master no indeed, for then he should have lied,
My cocke is I thank Christ, safe and well a fine.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Yea but that ragged colt, that whore that tyb of thine
Said plainly thy cocke was stolen, and in my house was eaten,
That lying cut is lost, that she is not swinged and beaten,
And yet for all my good name, it were a small amends
I pick not this gear (hearst thou) out of my fingers ends
But he that hard it told me, who thou of late didst name
Diccon whom all men knows, it was the very same.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: This is the case, you lost your needle about the doors
And she answers again, she has no cocke of yours,
Thus in you talk and Action, from that you do intend,
She is whole five mile wide, from that she doth defend:
will you say she hath your Cocke?

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: No merry sir that I will not,

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Will you confess her needle?

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Will I? no sir will I not.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Then there lieth all the matter.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Soft master by the way,
Ye know she could do little, and she could not say nay.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Yea but he that made one lie about your Cock stealing,
Will not stick to make another, what time lies be in dealing
I wean the end will prove, this brawl did first arise,
Upon no other ground, but only Diccons lies.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Though some be lies as you belike have espied them.
Yet other some be true, by proof I have well tried them.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: What other thing beside this dame Chat.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Marry sir even this,
The tale I told before, the self same tale it was his,
He gave me like a friend, warning against my loss,
Else had my hens be stolen, each one, by Gods cross:
He told me Hodge would come, and in he came indeed,
But as the matter chanced, with greater haste than speed,
This truth was said, and true was found, as truly I report.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: If Doctor Rat be not deceived, it was of another sort.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: By Gods mother thou and he, be a couple of subtle foxes,
Between you and Hodge, I bear away the boxes,
Did not diccon appoint the place, where you shouldst stand to mete him.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Yes by the mass, and if he came, bad me not stick to speet him .

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Gods sacrament the villain knave hath dressed us round about,
He is the cause of all this brawl, that dirty shitten lout:
When gammer gurton here complained, and made a rueful moan
I heard him swear that you had gotten, her needle that was gone,
And this to try he further said, he was full loath how be it
He was content with small ado, to bring me where to see it.
And where ye sat, he said full certain, if I would follow his read
Into your house a privy way, he would me guide and lead,
And where ye had it in your hands, sewing about a clout,
And set me in the back hole, thereby to find you out:
And whilst I sought a quietness, creeping upon my knees,
I found the weight of your door bar, for my reward and fees,
Such is the luck that some men gets, while they begin to mel
In setting at one such as were out, minding to make all well.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Was not well blessed gamer, to scape the scour, if I had been there
Then I had been dressed be like, as ill by the mass, as gaffer vicar.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Marry sir, here is a sport alone, I looked for such an end
If diccon had not played the knave, this had been soon amend
My gammer here he made a fool, and dressed her as she was
And goodwife Chat he set to scole, till both parts cried alas,
And D. Rat was not behind, whilst Chat his crown did pare,
I would the knave had be stark blind, if hodg had not his share.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: I am meetly well sped already among, I am dressed like a colt
And I had not had the better wit, I had been made a dolt.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Sir knave make haste diccon were here, fetch him where ever he be

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Fie on the villain, fie, fie, that makes us thus agree,

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: Fie on him knave, with all my heart, now fie, and fie again .

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Now fie on him may I best say, whom he hath almost slain.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Lo where he cometh at hand, belike he was not fare
Diccon hear be two or three, thy company cannot spare.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: God bless you, and you may be blessed so many all at once

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Come knave, it were a good deed to geld thee by cock's bones
Seest not thy handiwork? sir Rat can ye forbear him?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: A vengeance on those hands lite, for my hands cam not near him
The whoreson priest hath lift the pot, in some of these alewives chairs
That his head would not serve him, belike to come down the stayres.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: Nay soft, thou mayst not play the knave, and have this language too
If thou thy tong bridle a while, the better mayst thou do,
Confess the truth as I shall ask, and cease a while to fable.
And for thy fault I promise thee , thy handling shall be reasonable
Hast thou not made a lie or two, to set these two by the ears?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: What if I have? five hundred such have I seen within these seven years:
I am sorry for nothing else but that I see not the sport
Which was between them when they met, as they themselves report

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: The greatest thing master rat, ye se how he is dressed.

sp.speaker: Diccon.
sp.l: What devil need he be groping so deep, in goodwife Chats hens nest

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Yea but it was thy drift to bring him into the briars.

sp.speaker: Diccon.
sp.l: Gods bread, hath not such an old fool, wit to save his ears?
He showeth himself herein ye see, so very a cox,
The Cat was not so madly allured by the Fox,
To run into the snares, was set for him doubtless,
For he leapt in for mice, and this sir Iohn for madness.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Well if ye shift no better, ye losel, lither, and lazy,
I will go near for this, to make ye leap at a Daisy.
In the kings name master Bayly, I charge you set him fast.

sp.speaker: Diccon.
sp.l: What fast at cards, or fast on sleep? it is the thing I did last.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Nay fast in fetters false varlet, according to thy deeds.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Master doctor there is no remedy, I must entreat you needs
Some other kind of punishment,

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Nay by all Hallows.
His punishment if I may judge, shall be naught else but the gallows.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: That were too sore, a spiritual man to be so extreme.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: Is he worthy any better, sir how do ye judge and deem?

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: I grant him worthy punishment, but in no wise so great.

sp.speaker: Gamer
sp.l: It is a shame I tell you plain, for such false knaves entreat
He has almost undone us all, that is as true as steel:
And yet for all this great a do, I am never the near my needle.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Canst you not say any thing to that diccon, with least or most?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Yea marry sir, thus much I can say well, the needle is lost.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Nay canst not thou tell which way, that needle may be found

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: No by my fay sir. though I might have an hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Thou liar lickdish, didst not say the needle would be gotten?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: No hodge, by the same token, you were that time beshitten?
For fear of Hobgoblin, you wot well what I mean,
As long as it is sense, I fear me yet ye be scarce clean.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: Well master rat, you must both learn, and teach us to forgive
Since Diccon hath confession made, and is so clean shrive,
If ye to me consent, to amend this heavy chance.
I will enjoin him here, some open kind of penance:
Of this condition, where ye know my fee is twenty pence
For the bloodshed, I am agreed with you here to dispense,
Ye shall go quite, so that ye grant, the matter now to run,
To end with mirth among us all, even as it was begun.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: Say yea master vicar, and he shall sure confess to be your debter
